head.title: Surcharge on Fuel Raises Air Fares in U.S.

hedline.hl1: Surcharge on Fuel Raises Air Fares in U.S.

abstract.p: All major US airlines except Southwest, citing jet fuel price increase, impose surcharge that results in $20 hike in domestic round-trip fares (S)

block.p: Domestic round-trip air fares rose $20 in early September when all of the major airlines except Southwest imposed a surcharge that the industry said is necessary to offset the recent increase in the price of jet fuel.

The surtax, the second this year, was initiated by Continental Airlines and promptly matched by American, America West, Delta, Northwest, United, US Airways and T.W.A. -- airlines that carry about 90 percent of the nation's domestic passengers.

Domestic round-trip air fares rose $20 in early September when all of the major airlines except Southwest imposed a surcharge that the industry said is necessary to offset the recent increase in the price of jet fuel.

The surtax, the second this year, was initiated by Continental Airlines and promptly matched by American, America West, Delta, Northwest, United, US Airways and T.W.A. -- airlines that carry about 90 percent of the nation's domestic passengers.

In addition to Southwest -- which in March added a fuel surtax from $2 to $8 depending on the length of the flight, but said it would not go along with the latest hike -- AirTran Airways and most regional and low-fare airlines also have not added the surtax.

Continental did not give details about its surtax decision, which was announced on the same day that crude-oil futures closed above $35.39 a barrel, the highest in nine years (it has since risen an additional $2). (Airline fuel costs, like the cost of gasoline, move virtually in tandem with increases in the price of crude oil.) But Northwest said that each one-cent increase in the price of fuel costs the airline $29 million to $30 million.

In addition, the airline industry trade group, the Air Transport Association, has estimated that fuel will cost the carriers $5.5 billion more this year than in 1999, when it cost $10.4 billion. Through June of this year, the latest month for which figures are available, aviation fuel was up 59.5 percent, compared with a 3.6 increase for all of 1999. The price of aviation fuel averaged 75 cents a gallon in that six-month period, compared with an average 53.1 cents a gallon in 1999 and 51.3 cents in 1998. Aviation fuel currently averages about $1 a gallon.
